story_prompt: You are a beekeeper. You have a special relationship with your bees. You are able to communicate with them and they’re intelligent enough to see you removing honey as “rent”. This year things are different. The new queens are politely requesting that you invest some money to improve the hives.
output:
As you sit in your garden, surrounded by the buzzing of the hive, a warm sunbeam falls upon you, illuminating your face. Your mind races with thoughts of how to handle this unprecedented request from your bees. On one hand, you value your relationship with them and want to maintain their trust. On the other, you're worried about the practicality of such an ask.
    
You've always prided yourself on being frugal and self-sufficient, relying solely on your bees for honey and pollen. But now, as you listen to the gentle hum of the worker bees, you begin to ponder the idea of investing in better equipment or expanding the hive. It seems crazy, but the more you think about it, the more plausible it becomes.
    
After all, you reason, the bees are the ones doing all the hard work. They deserve a comfortable home and adequate resources to thrive. As you mull over the possibilities, you hear a rustling in the distance. A closer inspection reveals a group of ants marching towards the hive, no doubt drawn by the sweet scent of honey. You quickly scramble to your feet, ready to defend your bees against any potential threat.
    
As you stand guard, watching the ants approach cautiously, a thought strikes you - maybe this is exactly what your bees need. Perhaps by providing them with better resources, you can foster a sense of community and unity within the hive. It’s unconventional, sure, but could it be the key to a happier, healthier colony? With renewed purpose, you rush inside to gather materials for your bees. 
    
The ants may have been a wake-up call, but you know you have to take action soon. Time is of the essence when it comes to nurturing your bees and securing their future. As you scour your garden for suitable materials, you can’t help but feel a sense of pride and responsibility. You may be just one person to the outside world, but in the eyes of your bees, you’re so much more. Their protector, provider, and friend.
